Name: Clearly articulates questions in both verbal and written forms
Shares information about their own and their team's progress—successes, difficulties, failures, and delays when asked
Doesn’t withhold or manipulate information and its distribution for anyone's benefit
Communicates with others politely and with empathy, understands that people come from different cultures and backgrounds
Doesn’t wait for someone else to tell them what to do
Able to ask for clarification or for help when struggling
Shows interest and motivation when working without external motivation
Faces new situations with curiosity
Has daily conversations with the team about the progress of their work
Delivers on commitments while understanding their importance and priority
Solves simple and well-defined tasks by themselves
Can split work into actionable chunks with the assistance of others
Recognizes large or complex problems and involves the team for assistance
Understands general company customer needs. Knows how our customers do their job and how are we helping them. Knows what products do we offer
Understands business priorities and ways how company and team decisions support those.• Learns their team's domain (e.g. email, scheduling, mobile, internal tooling) and their customers needs
Able to adjust priorities, scope and quality with guidance from others
Aware of the code quality practices and understands the reasons behind them and practices some of them
Can reason about and understand existing non-complex code
Able to document solutions and explain their decisions
Performs code reviews regularly without a need to be explicitly asked
Asks questions in PR about code which they don't understand
Able to find typos and code inconsistency in any code
Finds possible issues in known components
Understands the architecture and design used in the team on the level that allows them to independently work on tasks, avoiding duplication across codebases and interface-breaking changes
New code is aligned with the team architecture and company best practices
Helps answer questions in public channels
Is aware of CI/CD pipeline and tools the team is using
Knows how to rollback to working version of the module in case of an incident
Is aware of monitors and alerts in the team
Understands the agile delivery process
Spots tasks which are too big when they work on it
Communicates dependencies and potential blockers
Ensures that tasks are appropriately sized for incremental delivery with help from others
Understands and acts according to task prioritisation
Communicates with task stakeholders (PM, Design) to clarify and review their work
Able to estimate a task
Understands company, team and project goals and always working towards them
Always asks for clarification if something is unclear
Sometimes supports their teammates in an open, respectful, flexible, empathetic manner (for example: helping with learning technical skills or overcoming technical challenges)
Helps with onboarding newcomers
Make decisions where necessary information is available
With guidance, are able to handle risk, change, and uncertainty within their personal scope of work effectively
Ensures that all relevant parties are involved
Organizes meetings, finds the most suitable time for all participants
Is responsible for agenda and results of the meeting
Performs basic meeting facilitation
Clearly expresses thoughts and ideas, listens, and is approachable
Has an ability to relay information openly and transparently
Habitually shares information with others inside and outside the company
Open-mindedness and a habit of learning from others regardless of their position or experience
Ability to admit being wrong or not knowing something
Clarifies information when it's vague or confusing
Written communication is concise and clear
Identifies situations where others in the company could benefit from the information they know, and shares it (guilds, team TEX-es).
Practices active listening techniques towards the team
Identifies how written communication can be received differently by others, and switches communication mediums and styles to convey a clear and kind message
Holds constructive, objective, and critical discussions on controversial issues with difficult audiences
Quickly extracts core issues from discussions and meetings. Their presence makes meetings more productive
Effectively promotes company branding through several public communication initiatives such as public speaking (e.g., Meetups) or blog post writing
Others often seek out their advice on matters involving communication
Not only practices mindful communication and active listening in interactions, but fosters these practices in others
Ability to work with others, providing support and assistance to achieve team goals
Great things are achieved by teams and the person accepts that the team is collectively smarter than them alone
Open to collaboration: joining workshops, pair programming, accepts help when stuck
Offers help when others say they're stuck
Verifies their opinion with facts. Changes opinion in face of clearly disproving information
Initiates pair programming and other ways to solve problems through team member collaboration
Shares the blame when something goes wrong, fixes team delivery problems regardless of who caused it
Shares the team's responsibilities and ensures the credit is shared
Willing to lose an argument to move forward
Contributes to a culture of continuous improvement on a project level
Makes sure that teammates have what they need to contribute to team success
Values the team and team’s results above personal success
Finds the best solution is more important than just being right
Able to notice overwhelmed colleagues, supports and distributes their work among the team to be more equally spread
Fosters a culture of continuous improvement on a team level
Fosters support and collaboration in the tribe
Fosters a culture of continuous improvement on the company level
Organizes workshops, TEXs, knowledge sharing session with the whole company
Others look forward to working with them
Helps teams outside of the company
Openness towards both receiving and giving feedback
Makes it easy for others to give feedback
Knows how to deliver praise and constructive feedback in a useful manner
Gets better through delivering some praise and critique to their teammates
Makes it easy for others to give feedback to them. Shows appreciation, isn't defensive, actively listens and tries to understand the feedback
Admits they don't know everything and that they have something to learn from others
Seeks advice without a concern about how others will perceive them
Regularly delivers praise and constructive critique to their teammates.
Delivers feedback not only to their peers, but also to other roles they collaborate with when an opportunity arises
Actively seeks out feedback from their teammates and project leaders
Uses the received feedback as a tool for growth. Demonstrates actions made based on feedback
Consistently gives good quality feedback, both praise and suggestions for improvement
Proactively and regularly delivers constructive feedback to the people they collaborate with
Not afraid to speak truth to power, and as such is trusted by the business to have an honest opinion
Practices radical candor—timely, clear and directed feedback
Works on a project level to  foster a culture of seeking out feedback and using it as a tool for growth
Asks for ad-hoc feedback in appropriate situations (important presentation, discussion, interviews, etc.)
Works on a team-level to foster a culture of seeking out feedback and using it as a tool for growth
Fosters a culture of delivering praise and constructive feedback within their team
Others turn to them for help giving difficult feedback
Helps with implementing the best practices for giving feedback across teams
Fosters feedback culture

Actively seeks solutions they believe will unblock the progress in their work
Proactively stepping up and taking ownership of problems which are not owned by anyone within their role context
Accountable for the quality of the outcome of their team
